column1: That evening we almost had a visit from one of the animals we were after. Several times we had heard at night the musical calling of the bull elk—a sound to which no writer has as yet done justice. This particular night
column2: when we were in bed and the fire was smoldering
column3: we were roused by a ruder noise—a kind of grunting or roaring whine
column4: answered by the frightened snorts of the ponies. It was a bear which had evidently not seen the fire
column5: as it came from behind the bank
column6: and had probably been attracted by the smell of the horses. After it made out what we were
column7: it stayed round a short while
column8: again uttered its peculiar roaring grunt
column9: and went off; we had seized our rifles and had run out into the woods
column10: but in the darkness could see nothing; indeed it was rather lucky we did not stumble across the bear
column11: as he could have made short work of us when we were at such a disadvantage.
